Review Text: I visited Thirukoneswaram Kovil in Trincomalee last week, and once again it reminded me why this temple is so special. This was my third visit, and every time I come here, the experience feels new, peaceful, and deeply spiritual. The moment you step inside the kovil, you can feel the calmness. The sea breeze, the ancient architecture, and the powerful energy of the place make your mind completely relaxed. The view from the top is truly breathtaking — the blue ocean stretching far beyond your eyes. It feels like nature itself is giving you a blessing. The temple premises are well maintained and very clean. Watching people pray with devotion, hearing the bells, and standing in front of Lord Shiva’s sanctum gives a beautiful sense of peace. Every visit makes me feel more connected to my faith and culture. If you are visiting Trincomalee, Thirukoneswaram Kovil is a must-visit, not just for religious reasons but also for the history, beauty, and the peaceful atmosphere it offers. I know this won’t be my last visit — this temple always pulls me back with its divine charm.

No admission fee, you make a free donation when you get your shoes back. The temple had an important destiny during the 1st millennium AD. Dating back to BC, successive kings gave it scope and fame. At the beginning of the 17th century, fearing a Portuguese invasion, the religious and notables of Trincomalee threw into the sea, just below the cliff on which the temple is erected, the important pieces to escape the invader. They were attacked: in 1623, the Portuguese took the city and razed the temple. It was not until 1950 that divers (including science fiction writer Arthur Clarke) rediscovered these submerged remains. The coins are reassembled and used to reconstruct the current temple, associated with more recent elements. Some of the pieces have remained underwater, just above the cliff, and are an extraordinary diving spot. Koneswaram means "where Shiva is". A grand Shiva status is at the entrance to the temple. The interior consists of mystical scenes and religious effigies. Just at the entrance to the cliffside path, a tree collects wooden crates that the faithful hang on its branches. These are symbolized cradles, with the tree receiving prayers related to fertility requests.

The Temple of the Thousand Pillars and Dakshina-Then Kailasam (Southern / Ancient Kailash) is a classical-medieval Hindu temple complex in Trinco, a Hindu religious pilgrimage centre in Eastern Province, Sri Lanka. The most sacred of the Pancha Ishwarams of Sri Lanka, it was built significantly during the ancient period on top of Konesar Malai, a promontory overlooking Trincomalee District, Gokarna Bay and the Indian Ocean. The monument contains its main shrine to Shiva in the form Kona-Ishvara, shortened to Konesar. The complex was destroyed in colonial religious attacks between 1622 and 1624 and a fort was built at the site from its debris. A 1632-built temple located away from the city houses some of its original idols. Worldwide interest was renewed following the discovery of its underwater and land ruins, sculptures and Chola bronzes by archaeologists and Arthur C. Clarke. It has been preserved through restorations, most recently in the 1950s. Granted ownership of villages in its floruit to form the Trincomalee District, Trincomalee village is located on the cape isthmus within the compounds. Revenue from the temple provides services and food to residents. Koneswaram has many strong historical associations. The shrine is described in the Vayu Purana, the Konesar Kalvettu and Tevaram hymns by Sambandhar and Sundarar as a Paadal Petra Sthalam along with its west coast Ishwaram counterpart Ketheeswaram temple, Mannar, and was praised for its tradition by Arunagirinathar upon his visit. The Dakshina Kailasa Puranam and Manmiam works note it as Dakshina/Then Kailasam (Mount Kailash of the South) for its longitudinal position and pre-eminence, it lies directly east of Kudiramalai west coast Hindu port town, while it is the easternmost shrine of the five ancient Ishwarams of Shiva on the island. Surrounded by the dramatic Swami Rock and Gokarna Bay, the classical-medieval complex is Trinco’s biggest draw. The site is a major Hindu pilgrimage center, and one of the Pancha Ishwarams (five abodes of Shiva) built in Sri Lanka to honor one of the principle deities of Hinduism. This temple is situated in the village of Thambalagamuwa that was part of the medieval semi-independent feudal division called Thambalagamuwa Pattu. Prior to the arrival of Portuguese in 1622 and then Dutch colonial overloads in 1656, leaders of the Thambalagamuwa Pattu and others around it were independent rulers sometimes subject to Jaffna kingdom or Kandyan kingdom.

What struck me most were the little colourful baskets, said to be small versions of baby cots, hanging on one of the trees towards the sea side under flags of various colours.  These are offerings from childless couples asking for divine intervention for them to have their baby. We spent a thoroughly enjoyable morning visiting this beautiful and historic location.

Visiting the Siva Ishwarams (Pancha Ishwarams) in Sri Lanka. The reunion with relatives in Jaffna took us to four of the Siva Temples in Sri Lanka during the first seven days of our Sri Lanka Odyssey. Our first stop, on March 3rd, was at the Munneswaram temple situated in a village in the Puttalam District. Hindus believe that it is one of the the five temples they need to visit in their life time. The others being Naguleswaram temple which we visited in Keerimalai in the Kankesanthurai district on March 4th and Thiruketheeshwaram in Mannar District and the Koneswaram temple in Trincomalee (Thirukonamalai) -- both the next day. All these, including Rameswaram in India form the five ancient temples (Ishwarams) dedicated to Shiva. According to Hindus, the Munneswaram temple near Puttalam is the temple where King Rama prayed to Shiva after killing Ravana to seek forgiveness over the death of many in the war. Hindus believe that the Naguleswaram temple's adjacent water tank, the Keerimalai Springs, has curative properties. The temple was largely destroyed by Jesuit missionaries following the Portuguese conquest of the Jaffna kingdom, restored by Arumuga Navallar in 1894. The Thiruketheeshwaram temple had existed for more than 2,400 years. During our visit to this temple, we witnessed a temple devotee from Vavunia singing Thevarams. His aim was to complete the 800 thurmurai thevarams in one month. The Trincomelee Koneswaram temple was built by the Cholas/Pandian kings. The temple is situated atop Konesar Malai, at a commanding position overlooking the Indian Ocean. It is also known as the "Mount Kailash of the South". The temple, mentioned in Mahabaratha and Ramayana, was visited by Arunagirinathar and is the easternmost shrine of the five ancient Ishwarams of Shiva on the island.

One of the most ancient temples of South Asia ,dedicated to Lord Shiva, dates back to the period of Rama mythologically,  and to the 6th Century B by historians. Said to have been worshiped by Ravana , ithe temple had one of the Suyambu Lingams as the main deity. During the 17th Century AD ( around 1630 s) the temple was supposed to have been razed to the ground by foreign invaders to build a harbour. The local priests hurriedly burred the important idols of the Gods before leaving the temple , fearing vandalism. And in 1956, in an underwater exploration , the old temple ruins were found, Besides a lot of inscriptions about the temple etc were also discovered . All the bits and pieces dicovered were put together and now a grand temple is there once again for us to worship. A great work of reconstruction of the temple as well as the history. The temple is sung about gloriously by the great poet saints. Sambandhar and Arunagirinathar. the Pandya Chola and Chera kings of south India  were said to have patronized and visited the temple.The Vilva tree is the Sacred tree of this temple. In 2013, when the civil works were undertaken for the temple, a beautiful Nandhi idol was discovered and it was found to belong to 11th Centurt AD. People believe that there many be many more to be excavated. The temple is also a seat of Sakthi Peetam, where the feet of the Amman were supposed to have been assocoated.

The Most Sacred Śrī Śānkarī Dévi Temple (Thiru Konéśwaran Koil) complex is located within the sprawling old Portuguese Fort. From the parking lot there is a 10-minute–walk up to the Temple. Among the several foreign visitors we met German, Spanish, Italian, Scottish and Chinese tourists. That shows the popularity of this place. Laxmi’s long-term wish got fulfilled this evening after we were blessed with a very happy and blissful Divine Sight of Śrī Śānkarī Dévi and Her Lord Śrī Śiva in this only Śakti Peeţhaṃ in Sri Lanka – known locally as Konéśwara Ālayaṃ – Śrī Mahā Śakti Peeţhaṃ Temple - of the eighteen (the remaining seventeen being located in India) at this MOST SACRED PLACE in Trincomalee. The surrounding views are full of greenery and so beautiful. The blue Indian Ocean appearing on both sides of the Temple Complex presented a lovely spectacle! The Scottish couple took me to be a Guide and said they were not going to pay me anything when I volunteered to explain the story of Śrī Mārkaṇḑéya in the complex. However, they were very happy to listen to the Purāṇic legend narrated by me - about Sage Mārkaṇḑéya as even the God of Death Yama had to take off his crown and mace and surrender totally before Lord Siva when commanded by Siva to spare the life of His devotee Mārkaṇḑéya!  They profusely thanked me after hearing my narration and felt so happy knowing that I was a student at the Imperial College, London, long time ago but  that I was not a Guide! The Scotsman respectfully took off his hat and bowed before Lord Śiva in reverence. It was learnt that the Portuguese who were in occupation of Sri Lanka in the 16 Century AD destroyed the original Temple and threw all the magnificent sculptured stone columns down into the sea below. Three bronze statues were lately brought up by divers, found among the columns buried in the sea, one of which has been mounted atop the hill facing the entrance to the renovated Temple. The Temple opened at 5 O’Clock in the evening. The Tamil priests first performed the prescribed customary rituals to the Lord. We have then made our own humble offerings to the Presiding Deity Śrī Śānkarī Dévi. We had the Most Divine Sight and blessings of the Holy Lord and His Divine Consort while witnessing in awe all the Pūja Worships done by the Tamil priests in the huge, peaceful and Serene complex.

As with almost all kovils in Sri Lanka, pictures are not allowed inside the main temple but men do not have to take their shirts off. The puja itself is more subdued compared to the ones we have observed in other parts of Sri Lanka.

The Koneswaram Hindu Temple is definitely a 'must see' when in Trincomalee. One has to walk for a few minutes along the road leading to it (with no shoes), then a short climb up into the Temple itself. You pass numerous street vendors selling sweet foods, hats and souvenirs. The Temple itself is a masterpiece of architecture and Hindu decorations and art work. Apart from the glory of the Temple one can enjoy superb panoramic views from the grounds, overlooking the town and distant beaches.

A great place for theologians and others seeking insights on the Ramayana! The place is situated with a great panoramic view of the city and sea! A must for visitors to this city! Dressing must be decent in view of religious sentiments and taboo. The pictures and paintings inside which includes archeological findings really heartwarming and breathtaking! The stalls leading to the temple a great place for souvenirs and fair priced! But please do bargain for a great deal! Do not miss catching a glimpse of the deers!
Walk around a Hindu temple barefoot. Look at the ocean and get a taste of Tamil culture. Just a short walk from the bus station. Not to mention the very tame deer.
Koneswaram Temple is an  Interesting Place to visit and study. A history of decades and we had a wonderful time.
evidence for ramayana in this koneshwaram temple is rawana cut. though you believe or not there is a cut shape in stone. sacred place. nice place. easily can reach from trincomalee town.
This ancient Kovil has a history of being a magnet for childless women. You will see toy cradles hung on a tress by women praying for a child.

There is parking available at this temple free of charge. The walk to the temple is quite short but a little on the hilly side. There are stalls selling offerings to take with you to the temple and also stalls selling drinks and ice-creams. Once you get closer to the temple you have to remove your shoes as usual and pay Rupees 20.00 to reclaim them again. The ground in the afternoon to the temple once you remove your shoes can be rather challenging as it becomes very hot. The temple itself is well worth a visit and the views from the top are truly magnificent. Sadly there are many spotted deer that have taken residency next to the temple, and have begun to beg for food from the devotees. Many people, including ourselves, stop to take photographs of the resident spotted deer. I only hope that people do not get them too familiar with begging for food due to feeding, that they completely forget how to forage for themselves.

Koneswaram temple is a hindu temple an dknown as teh first among the shakti peetams .. very very nice .. well maintained ,clean and perfect place to worship... as the place is visited by many Indians  .. they are accepting Indian currency also....
went and had a look, wasn't planning on it, but we went; had to remove shoes, put on sarong, but no worries. be respectful of people worshiping, and taking photos without asking.

Visited on an early morning excursion with the family. Love the rich colours of this temple and with few people around you got a definite sense of peace and calm which was appreciated. Lots of little nooks and crannies with different deities and enjoyed the views of the Indian Ocean as well. Would definitely recommend any travellers to Trinco to tick this exquisite temple off the list.

A picturesque stroll from the fort that borders the temple allows amazing views back over Dutch bay and Trinco town. There is a number of vendors just before the entrance, selling an array of gifts for the locals. Do yourself a favour and sample some of the sweets, they are delightful. The temple itself is visited by large numbers of locals, making the short walk.
Surrounded by sea with colourful temple. God koneswar one of the ancient temple for Hindus. Very silence and peaceful for mind

This is a beautiful temple with a lot of old artifacts and history dating back to the time of King Ravana. The location is fabulous, with views of the Trincomalee town and the beaches from the temple.
Mostly Hindu devotees visited to this place for engage with their religious works .Beyond that it is wonderful creature of nature. Every one should visit this place.

Very crowded, interesting place. You dont see many tourists there. On the way to the temple you can buy tacky, chinese stuff and snacks. The temple is worth to see. Very colorful and the way through the Fort is nice

While I stood through the morning service I can't pretend to really understand what was going on but the Faithful were clearly enraptured by the spectacle. Later we went along the cliff-edge path with great views of the ocean. Those unused to walking barefooted should be aware that you have to leave your shoes a fair distance from the temple so socks may be a good idea in the heat of the day.
It´s a nice and peaceful place with a very good view. We walked up to the hill... would do it again...

No visit to Trincomalee would be complete without visiting Koneswaram Temple. We were in a self drive car so were only required to walk the 500 or so metres from the car park, but from Trincomalee town it is a bit of an uphill trek particularly in the very hot conditions. As with all Hindu temples shoes are not allowed within the temple or the immediate surrounding area, so a pair of socks is a good idea to protect against the hot sand and gritty ground. Entry is free but shoes must be deposited at a kiosk for which a small fee of 20 rupees is charged.  The views from the temple are stunning particularly over 'lovers leap'.

I had a tuk tuk take me it's lovley entrance old fort. But army still there  staying and looking after it  big grounds lots of deer my driver took food and they came right up  eat out our hands. No shoes at temple  my driver was explaining things which made it far more interesting there was a bit that was locked  this is for people's safety there's been a lot of people taken ther life's there The views are amazing

This ancient Hindu Temple dedicated to Shiva has indie interesting murals of Ravana, the Shiva devotee. We were present for the evening Aarti and it was very nice to see the devotion and faith of the people. Ravana's cut - in the rocks outside the temple has an interesting story

We walked here from Trinco center. It was about a 3km walk and took about 45 minutes one way. This temple sit at the top of Swami rock. Along the way, near the top there are restaurants and many souvenir shops. At the top sits a giant blue Shiva as well as a beautiful Temple with many beautiful murals. There is no fee. There is a scenic walk along the cliff decorated with 3D Hindu stories. Take socks to protect your feet from the hot sand. You must take off your shoes....there is a shoe fee. The walk takes you thru Fort Fredrick, and past a path leading to a Buddhist Stupa.

This Hindu temple is located like many places in a beautiful spot, but this one has a great view over the Indian ocean and the Dutch harbour. We where informed that it is the 5th biggest natural harbour in the world! Fort Frederick is a delightful park and contains both colonial buildings and are still used today by the Sri Lankan army. Temple lover or not, it´s worth the visit while in Trincolombee!

A very famous Hindu shrine just few min from Trinco town, this place is located in an old dutch fort and army camp. but you can just visit without any issues and a daily visited place by Tamil people around. and its a local attraction too. the shrine is on the edge of a peninsula , and it has nice views of sea from very high point  as it is on a rock mountain surrounded by sea.

If you are in Trinco this is definitely worth a visit. The temple is beautiful and the location on top of Swami Rock offers great views. Lots of wild deer as well. Head up in the early evening to watch the sunset.  Beautiful place.
Good temple. Learned new stories about Ravana. The temple is very neat and clean and offers excellent views of Indian Ocean.

This is the best place in trincomalee to spend your evening. This place is inside the fort. If you are walking towards the temple, there is a high probability that you will see plenty of deers who actually do not care who is around. They are quite used to people around and will not run away, so plenty of time to click a pic! As the temple is on a cliff, you get a wide view of the oceans and speed boats. There is also a lover 's leap here..which is a scary drop from the cliff. The temple premises has several gods and goddesses statues and pictures on the wall. There is a huge Shiva statute just outside the premises and visible from quite a distance. Tip: Do not forget to shop for local items just outside the temple complex. You can busy certain packed items to eat which are local delicacies, jewelry and craft work at a very reasonable price. Still, you can bargain to get a better price. Irrespective of that the prices are very reasonable and a good point to shop for souvenirs.

It was a fun experience to leave your shoes behind for 20 rupees and walk past wild deer going up to the temple. The area is actually pretty small and there is construction around 30% of the sides which takes a little of the magic away, but it's still amazing to see. Photos are only allowed outside but you can enjoy seeing the devout cracking coconuts on rocks outside, and inside the temple if you time it right you can witness one of the ceremonies with music, smoke, flowers - it's pretty great. Not much else to do besides that - we were only there about 20 minutes including watching the ceremony. As you go back down and collect your shoes there are some touristy stands. If you're in the Trinco area it's definitely a must see for the beautiful art and statue!

The view is breath taking from the top of the cliff. If you go in the early morning you can enjoy the sun rise from here. As well participate for a traditional Hindu prayer and learn a little bit of the Hindu culture and history.
It is a very bug temple and is also very peaceful. It has many god in there. The architecture is nicely done.
The best part of this location is you can get a breathtaking view of Trinco harbour. Apart from it, it's typical Hindu temple with lot of statues. You feel relaxed when going inside the temple.

The location of this temple complex is amazing. Right next to the ocean, Since it is on top of an hill, the views from the complex are breath taking. The temple is very religious and is in indian style.
The temple on the shore next above the sea level and one of the most prominent places in Srilanka.It is well maintained and very clean.The view from the temple also isvery good.

Had no idea what to expect but was surprised ,very interesting Hindu temple. Leave your shoes with the shoe man for 20rp wash your feet with the plastic cup and walk up the hot stairs to the entrance. Perched on a clifftop with great views out over the ocean. Apparently it's a green zone no plastic or rubbish allowed in but look over the fence and there it all is !! Why throw it over the fence at a sacred places I don't understand It's a beautiful place and it's treated like a tip. The temple itself is outstanding ,the artwork over the top and incredibly colorful. Definitely worth a visit

A beautiful temple located on the cliff with a amazing view of the ocean. The history of the temple either written in sinhala or tamil language. If someone could explain about the stories the visit would be more interesting.
A real must see when in trinco. The views from the temple are fantastic and well worth the effort. The temple is in an army fort so would recommend a tuk tuk or van to take you in.
Pretty awesome temple. Nothing is in English though... No shoes and must cover up! Although there isn't anything to read, it's still a wicked temple and calms you when you enter.
if your visit tricomali, this certainly is a comfortable place which is inevitable. you can feel clearly of the local flavor, but buy something local with local price too
Best to be there for the 6:30am Pooja - best time, great light and few people especially on weekdays

The Tirukoneswaran Hindu temple is situated in such a beautiful area that it is so serene to look around and feel blessed. The temple itself is very rich in history as this is the place where Lord Rama is supposed to have installed the second lingam after he defeated King Ravana of Lanka, on Lord Shiva's instructions. Beautiful Temple. A lot of vibrations. Many other sites in the temple area to see such as the Ravana statue and the Ravana cut, which has its own story.
Second visit to this temple. Definitely worth checking out. The view from the temple is amazing, but try and visit late in the day, ground is very hot during the middle of the day

Nice visit for free! You can also visit fort Frederic and a Buddhist temple there everything is free Entry! The solfiers there are very nice and caring that No Tourist pays money for something free! Nice people.
Don't ever miss this amazing temple. If you need a closer darshan inside the temple, you need to wear dhoti or saree. Else you can see from outer Praharam. Dont miss the beautiful sunset..

We family of 12 with chidren visited in the evening  .nice atmosphere, there are 3 wheelers who charge rs100 for tranporting from car park who cannot walk. It is surrounded by sea .this the temple where ravana worshipped lord shiva.
Koneswaram Temple is a scared place of hindu people, but people visit there without any racism. The geographical location is really great & you can see magnificent scenery at evening times.

You will be welcomed by the huge blue statue! For me this was the most interessting part. Take off shoes to enter the area and wear a sarong or long clothing. Fotos are not allowed inside the temple. Outside it is allowed. There is NO entrance fee to pay.
Colourful and very inviting temple.  Great place to see a sunset as well if you go in the cool if the early evening.

This is a very nice place and a must that you must do when visiting trinco. At night this place is soo calm and quiet that you can visit with your husband.Remember that the show protecting people will stop their job after 7pm

very colorful temple, no pictures are allowed inside, very decent drawings with a lot of colors. as you walk to it you can see a lot of antelopes, very nice scenery of the sea and good souvenir shops (you must bargain to get a good price)

Such a "BEAUTIFUL" place with so much history! I seriously don't have words to describe. Plus the day we went there,was so much crowded because it was a long weekend vacation here in SriLanka,so many people were their to enjoy the eastern atmosphere!

It is very much worth a visit as a break from the beach. It's at the top of a hill inside the Fort.  A car can take you most of the way up but you'll have to walk the last couple of hundred meters. You'll run a gauntlet of vendors. They are actually half the fun. You'll have to take your shoes off, and pay for the privilege, for about the last 100 meters. The pavement can be hot, very HOT. Even the locals were screaming and running for spots the sun wasn't hitting. Visiting early in the morning would probably solve that.

This is really worth a visit if you are staying around Trinco. It's location on a clifftop really adds to the atmosphere. Koneswaram temple is one of the few Hindu temples I have visited but definitely the most impressive with a huge statue of Lord Vishnu towering above the entrance and numerous, colourful examples of Hindu art both inside and out.
i love every inch of this place... the view was just breath taking, and the temple architecture was absolutely gorgeous

Koneswaram temple is very old and one of the most important Hindu temples in srilanka.. Very nice place with so much Divinity.. Lord shiva shower his unconditional love and blessings from this kovil. Temple has a long history of thousands of years and lot of miracles have taken place. The view from the temple is unbelievable and can see the beauty of trincomalee. A must place to visit
This temple is profound. One must experience it. Make sure to wear traditional dress if you want to do pooja offering.

We went there today and found it very beautiful and the paintings are amazing. So much colour! The only negative is the rubbish everywhere. I wish people would be more pro active in cleaning up their religious areas or stop throwing their rubbish off the grown, mostly out of respect.

While the statue at the front is impressive, the inside 3D frescoes are absolutely amazing.  No photography is allowed inside, but it is obvious that the devotees take a lot of care to maintain all the paintwork. We were in awe of how well cared for the temple was.

This is one of the beautiful Hindu Temple around the country. mainly with the location is very attractive, from this location you can see the city and Ocean.This Hindu Temple has a long History with God Shiva, and King Rawana.

Today's cultural program - visiting the temple of Shiva. Photo from outside, inside shooting is prohibited. On the altar was the Brahmin, we bought the strings for tying the hands and asked to offer them to Shiva lingam. Brahman asked our names, revered mantra, of which I recognized only Om Namah Shivaya. Shiva is very easy to be pleased, and he easily makes real all material desires. However, this makes you loose your piety (let's say your energy power). Be aware and well weigh whether you really need it or not  😀 Brahmin also looked at me and said "very nice dress for Sri Lanka culture". Whatever it meant 😀 🙏 I am delighted by the temple!
Pretty, lively and lovely with a real sense of occasion, was even blessed. Hot in the day and you have to take your shoes off, hard for westerners in 40 degree heat. Great place - go!
We walked up the temple starting from the beach and crossed Fort Frederick on the way. Nice sea views from the top. Nice to come at prayer times.
what a celebration of colors, smells, sounds and more....located on a very nice spot, overlooking the trincomalee bay and has a vey nice market. Recommended

Came here in the noon and had took off the shoes at the entrance. And the rest was running here and there to keep our feet from burning!!!! Nice views and history. But go there in the morning or eve for your feet sake.

A nice trip out, what a setting..set in a military fort you get to see a different side.  The temple is amazing, bare in mind the temperature of the floor as you do have to remove your shoes.... But lovely.
Visiting this beautiful temple late in the afternoon, we found ourselves almost intruding on everyday Hindu live. But we met only smiles from the people :) Impressive and worth a visite!
Travelled to this place on a three wheeler from JKAB Hotel. Enjoyed the beach and scenic view from the temple.

Really nice temple can get a little crowded worth a visit. P.s they make you take footwear off so on a hot day the floor will burn your feet I suggest taking a pair off socks to put on to protect feet :)
This is a hindu temple which is situated in trincomalee . place is very beautiful and it is a well known sacred place which fulfills wishes of women who are expecting babies .

This temple to the Hindu god Shiva is very colourful and there are a lot of historical pieces to see. Some of the details/history of the temple are in English but not all. It might be best to read a description of the temple online prior to entering. Cameras are not allowed inside the main part of the temple. Shoes are not allowed in any part of the temple grounds. Note the pavement will be extremely hot and difficult to walk on if you come during the day time - look for shady areas to walk on. Women must have the legs and shoulders covered before entering.
As you enter this place you can see loud music which can be for some people disturbing, but for me it was quite a fun. The place is very nice and offers a stunning ocean view.

Beautiful temple. The giant Shiva is reason enough to visit, but the temple itself is beautifully decorated with colorful paintings which are unlike anything I have ever seen in a temple. Try to go earlier in the morning since it is quite popular with locals too.
Come in the evening around 6 or 7 PM to see the amazing sunset from the top of the hill and the ceremony in the temple. One of the most beautiful temples we visited in Sri Lanka.

If Hindu temples are your thing this is the Grand Daddy of them all. Worth a visit. Just remember that with all religious sites no footwear can be worn and if it is hot you may need a good pair of thick socks.

This place is stunning but to my poor Western eyes it is most odd. The garish colours, the endless figures in strange mutations and poses... it is like a fever-dream and so hard to take in. The flames, prayer cloths and model cribs along with the chants, half naked priests and bells all add to the sense of other worldliness. I'm no closer to understanding Hinduism but I am intrigued and my children were fascinated by it all. Culturally important but difficult to access spiritually or educationally. A stunning place though and you must visit.

Impressive to see. Remember to put on long trousers or a long dress (and no bare shoulders) should you want to enter the temple. Shoes can be stored for 20 Roepies a pair close to the entrance of the premisses.

Very religious place to see. It's a very nice place near to the town and its on a hill mountain. The entrance to this temple falls from. The fort gates and it is being surrounded with the army camp. Very safe and any vehicle can be taken very near to the temple. The lovers leap is also is here and many tourist visit here and you can see from the sea level as well as from top. The shiva linga is there and many worshippers come to worship. Stay in trinco and enjoy the surroundings.

It's a great temple with lots of action going on. Drums and trumpets playing in a very nice and colorful temple. Lots to see for people who are new to Hinduism. The view from Swami Rock is great aswell, especially during sunset. Would advise to go one way at least by Tuk Tuk if you stay in Trincomalee.

Situated at the top of the hill within the fort, the building is very attractive and elegant with numerous figures upon parts of the roof and a very large statue of Shiva at the entrance. Quirky little place really and worth popping into if you're in the area.
Worth a visit because of the views. The temple is a temple. A lot of commercial stands before you enter.
Nice trip in 'trinc', views are superb, temple is beautiful Hindu piece of work, certainly worth the detour (entrance is free)

Was lovely and cool inside this air conditioned restaurant which was a bonus. Kids had pizzas which were fine but sadly my nasi gorang was burnt and every mouthful tasted of burnt rice which was very disappointing. I'm not one to complain but I won't be going back. Also were bothered by flies so waiter positioned a fan next to the table to try and blow them away from our food!

This temple is located inside of Fort Frederick in Trinco. It's an uphill path so a tuk tuk might help those with mobility issues, but it's not that hard to get to. You leave your shoes at the entrance and pay 20 rupees to get them back when you leave. I didn't heed the previous reviews and went barefooted and it is really hot on the soles of your feet, so be warned! The temple itself is beautiful - lots of colourful deities and carvings - when we got there, offerings were starting and so a lot of things were being covered up. this didn't detract from the experience overall, but just know that this sometimes happens. There's also an outdoor bit around the edge of the cliff - you can look out over the Bay of Bengal and hope to spot a whale. All in all, a lovely temple to visit - there's not much to do in Trinco, so definitely give this a shot!

This is a must see place if one visits Trinco. It is very easy to reach and you can take your vehicle quite close to the temple. It tells you many epic stories about the hindu gods and also offers some spectacular views (Ex: Lovers Leap). The views get even better if the sun is out nice and bright. Don't forget to see the Portuguese cemetery on your way.

You enter the temple after a nice walk down a winding road. As you turn into temple you see a HUGE statue of Lord Shiva - in bright blue ! The temple is not very big (unlike its counterparts in India), but airy and roomy. And  not very crowded like most temples in Sri Lanka... As you walk around the temple, its 2000+ year history begins to get into you ! The Bay looking stunning on the eastern periphery of the temple. Caution - the walk from the place you remove the footwear to the covered portion of the temple can be cruel on sensitive feet ! We reached at noon - and we really felt the heat. So plan your visit before 10 am or after 4 pm, if possible.
a little wark up to the temple ...quiet...u can see alot of deers on the road ...view from on top of the rock is nice  ..has a history ....

The location of the temple was interesting and the view was excellent from the top. The only difficulty was walking from the place you need to remove your foot wear walk barefoot for a person who is not used to. You are not permitted to take pictures inside the temple.
Worshipped and sung by noted scholars and spiritual gurus, this most sacred temple is where King Ravan was supposed to have prayed Lord Shiva.

Nice walk up the hill with fantastic nature and animal life, from the top you get a nice view of the ocean and city. The temple is beatiful, we enjoyed the view and freshly pressed juice before heading down again.
For me a person who has never bee to India, seeing hinduism practiced in front of me was an eye opening experience. The temple's architecture is fascinating!
The climb is easy by foot and the setting and view are spectacular. A giant Shiva welcomes you as you enter.
One of the great temples for the Lord Shiva and got the mention in the epic story of Ramayana and other devotional poems. It is believed King Ravana and his mum prayed there.
